title: Erkki Tuomioja
text:
Erkki Sakari Tuomioja (born 1 July 1946) is a <a href="Finland">Finnish</a> politician and a member of the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Finland">Finnish Parliament</a>. From 2000 to 2007 and 2011 to 2015, he served as the <a href="Minister%20for%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Finland%29">Minister for Foreign Affairs</a>. He was President of the <a href="Nordic%20Council">Nordic Council</a> in 2008.
Tuomioja is a member of the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Finland">Social Democratic Party of Finland</a>, although his political views are thought to be more to the left than the party line. He is also a member of <a href="ATTAC">ATTAC</a>. In <a href="1975">1975</a>, Tuomioja dated <a href="Tarja%20Halonen">Tarja Halonen</a> who later became the <a href="president%20of%20Finland">president of Finland</a>.
Tuomioja comes from a family of <a href="politician">politician</a>s. His father <a href="Sakari%20Tuomioja">Sakari Tuomioja</a> was a prominent <a href="National%20Progressive%20Party%20%28Finland%29">liberal</a> Finnish politician and diplomat, and the challenger of <a href="Urho%20Kekkonen">Urho Kekkonen</a> for the <a href="National%20Coalition%20Party%20%28Finland%29">conservatives</a> and liberals in the <a href="1956%20Finnish%20presidential%20election">1956 presidential elections</a>. His maternal grandmother was <a href="Hella%20Wuolijoki">Hella Wuolijoki</a>, the <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>n born writer and <a href="socialist">socialist</a> activist.
Tuomioja holds the degrees of Master of Social Sciences (1971) and Master of Science in Economics and Business Administration (1974) from the <a href="Helsinki%20School%20of%20Economics">Helsinki School of Economics</a>, as well as Licentiate in Social Sciences (1980) and Doctor in Social Sciences (1996) from the <a href="University%20of%20Helsinki">University of Helsinki</a>. In addition to <a href="Finnish%20language">Finnish</a>, Tuomioja speaks <a href="Swedish%20language">Swedish</a>, <a href="English%20language">English</a>, <a href="French%20language">French</a>, <a href="German%20language">German</a> and <a href="Estonian%20language">Estonian</a>.
Tuomioja has been a member of the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Finland">Finnish Parliament</a> 1970–1979 and 1991–present. He held the position of <a href="Minister%20of%20Trade%20and%20Industry%20%28Finland%29">Minister of Trade and Industry</a> in <a href="Paavo%20Lipponen">Lipponen's</a> 2nd government, and became the <a href="Minister%20for%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Finland%29">Minister of Foreign Affairs</a> after Tarja Halonen was elected the President of Finland. Tuomioja is the longest serving Minister for Foreign Affairs of Finland.
Tuomioja, like several other Finnish socialist politicians of today, took part in the illegal occupation of the Old Student House (Vanha ylioppilastalo) in <a href="Helsinki">Helsinki</a> on 25 November 1968. He was a member of the anti-war group Committee of 100 of Finland and took part in the so-called <a href="Erik%20Sch%C3%BCller">Erik Schüller</a> case, in which a group of students made public incitement against obligatory conscription. Despite his anti-war stance, Tuomioja did carry out his own mandatory military service and is a reservist staff sergeant.
Tuomioja is the author of several books. His "A Delicate Shade of Pink" about his grandmother <a href="Hella%20Wuolijoki">Hella Wuolijoki</a> and her sister <a href="Salme%20Murrik">Salme Murrik</a> won the Non-Fiction <a href="Finlandia%20Prize">Finlandia Prize</a> in 2006. The book was originally written in English and translated to Finnish as "Häivähdys punaista".
Tuomioja was behind the initiative to establish <a href="Historians%20without%20Borders">Historians without Borders</a> in Finland as an NGO. He has acted as Chairman of the Board of HWB Finland since the founding meeting in the summer of 2015. Tuomioja is a declared <a href="atheist">atheist</a>.
EU Presidency.
When <a href="Finland%27s%20EU%20Presidency">Finland</a> held the rotating <a href="EU%20Presidency">EU Presidency</a> in the second half of 2006, Tuomioja had a prominent role as the spokesman of <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> foreign policy. He was among the first to demand an immediate <a href="cessation%20of%20hostilities">cessation of hostilities</a> in the <a href="2006%20Israel-Lebanon%20conflict">2006 Israel-Lebanon conflict</a>. He was one of Finland's most dominant politicians in the 1990s.
